awd_abstract_narration:
Dmitrii E. Makarov of the University of Texas at Austin is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Division of Chemistry.  Biomolecules and their assemblies act as machines, performing myriads of tasks in living organisms.  These tasks include  the synthesis of other molecules, the transport of cargo across cells, generation of mechanical forces, recognition, signaling and others. An understanding of the microscopic chemical basis of these functions will enable the design of bioinspired materials and nanomachines.  Such understanding provides important insights into the molecular origins of diseases. A key challenge to achieving this goal is that many molecular motions, e.g. the “power stroke” of a molecular motor, are both too fast to observe via direct experiments and too slow to model on a computer.  The Makarov research group uses theory to bridge the gap between experimental observations in single molecule studies and computer simulations of biomolecules in action. Through synergy between experiments, theory, and molecular simulations, they are developing accurate models and theories to describe the motion of biomolecules as inferred directly from experimental observations. This project will increase integration of education and research through organization of a Summer School on molecular kinetics, organization of the Biophysics Day at UT Austin, involvement of undergraduate students in the PI's group research activities, and participation of students in scientific meetings.  Outreach efforts will include talks at Texas universities serving underrepresented groups, with the goal to establish relationships with students and faculty, and mentoring a competitive Science Olympiad team of middle and high school students.  The studies of the recently discovered novel mechanism of biomolecular interactions may have important implications in the biotechnology, as well as for the development of bioinspired materials with high toughness.

The research supported by this grant includes two major components. In the first component, a coherent picture of microscopic biomolecular dynamics at multiple timescales and at different levels (from atomistic to coarse, low-dimensional) of theoretical description is being developed, with the focus on the intrachain dynamics of intrinsically disordered proteins, biomolecular folding, and protein association, especially the formation of “fuzzy” protein complexes. The second component focuses on the dynamics of barrier crossing in nonequilibrium processes such as those underlying the action of molecular machines, with the goal to uncover underlying dynamics, beyond discrete states and transition rates, from high-temporal-resolution single-molecule data.  The group also seeks to elucidate how molecular machines break the symmetry between the forward and backward motion.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has resulted in development of a suite of computational and theoretical tools for the analysis and interpretation of single-molecule trajectories, partticularly those reporting on the function of (bio)molecular machines. Those tools address several key general questions:

  1. What is the adequate level of complexity required of mesoscopic models of molecular motion in order to faithfully capture experimental observations?  
  2. How can the thermodynamic cost of the function of molecular machines be quantified, given partial/incomplete experimental observables?
  3. How can the energy dissipation caused by fluctuating electric forces in the cell  be estimated?    
  4. What are the molecular timescales for slow conformational rearrangements in disordered biopolymers, particularly those associated with changes in the topology of the molecular system?
  5. How to account for/correct for limited experimental spatial and temporal resolution  when analyzing experimental data?

The speficic methodological developments include:

  1. A discovery that essential multidimensionality of the underlying energy landscape can be deduced from the shape of the probability distribution of the time it takes a molecular system to accomplish crossing of a free energy barrier
  2. Development of information theory tools (based on compression algorithms) that can inform one whether obsered molecular trajectories are simple random walks or they display history dependence
  3. Extension of compression-algorithm-based methods as tools for thermpodynamic inferrence from photon-by-photon single-molecule time series
  4. Development of dissipation-preserving methods for coarse graining of chemical reaction networks
  5. Theoretical description  of "failed barrier crossing attempts"  and other elementary events in barrier-crossing dynamics as  observed by single-molecule force-spectroscopy studies,  
  6. A theoretical description of nanopore translocation that includes multidimensional effects

This project has trained several graduate and undergraduate students, and a high-school student. Methods of non-equilibrium statistical mechanics were applied to the very different field of econophysics; by expoiting the analogy between wealth distributions in multi-agent models and energy distributions in nonequilibrium statistical mechanics, the PIs both proposed a new explanation of the Pareto law in ecomis and developed new teaching tools for statistical mechanics.   

The PI coorganized an international workshop on applications of data science to single-molecule chemistry and physics and a new seminar series for the University of Texases undergradautes, featuring College of Natural Sciences speakers.  Strong sceintific ties and collaborations have been established with multiple organizations including Weizmann Institute of Science, Max Planck Institute for Multidisciplinary Studies (Goettingen), Department of Physics at the University of Goettingen, Departments of Bioengineering and Chemistry at Rice University, and Department of Computer science at UT Austin, resulting in multiple joint publications with these instituttions.
